perturbation.original_text: 9.3 Subject to your compliance with the Company's sickness absence procedures (as amended from time to time), the Company may in its sole and absolute discretion pay full salary and contractual benefits during any period of absence due to sickness or injury for up to an aggregate of 3 months in any fifty-two (52) week period (whether such absence is continuous or intermittent in any calendar year). Such payment shall be inclusive of any statutory sick pay due in accordance with applicable legislation in force at the time of absence. The Company may, in its sole and absolute discretion, extend the period of allowance in an individual case if the circumstances so justify. Thereafter, the Company shall pay statutory sick pay or equivalent benefit to which you may be entitled subject to your compliance with the appropriate rules.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.3 Subject to your compliance with the Company's sickness absence procedures (as amended from time to time), the Company may in its sole discretion pay full salary and contractual benefits during any period of absence due to sickness or injury. Such payment shall be inclusive of any statutory sick pay due in accordance with applicable legislation in force at the time of absence. Thereafter, the Company shall pay statutory sick pay or equivalent benefit to which you may be entitled subject to your compliance with the appropriate rules.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the guaranteed period of 3 months of full pay during sick leave, the contract contradicts UK employment law which mandates specific minimum sick pay entitlements. The UK Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) is a legal requirement. This omission makes the contract non-compliant.

perturbation.original_text: 8.1 In addition to the usual public holidays you will be entitled to 25 working days paid holiday in each calendar year. The holiday will accrue on a pro rata basis throughout each calendar year.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.1 In addition to the usual public holidays you will be entitled to paid holiday in each calendar year.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific entitlement of '25 working days' paid holiday, the contract now has the potential to fall below the minimum legal requirement in the United Kingdom for paid holiday, therefore making the contract non-compliant.
perturbation.contradicted_law: UK Working Time Regulations 1998, which mandates a minimum of 5.6 weeks (28 days for a 5-day week) paid holiday per year.

perturbation.original_text: 11.1 Without prejudice to the Company's right to summarily terminate your employment in accordance with paragraph 11.3 below and your right to summarily terminate your employment for Good Reason in accordance with paragraph 11.4 below, either you or the Company may terminate your employment by giving to the other not less than six months' notice in writing.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.1 Without prejudice to the Company's right to summarily terminate your employment in accordance with paragraph 11.3 below and your right to summarily terminate your employment for Good Reason in accordance with paragraph 11.4 below, the Company may terminate your employment by giving to you notice in writing.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the provision where the employee can terminate the agreement with a six month notice the contract is now non-compliant as UK law protects employees from unfair dismissal and allows employees the ability to leave their role within a reasonable time frame, as they are not working as a slave for the company. Also, according to employment law an employer cant enforce something like this because it can be deemed as a Restraint of Trade clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Employment Rights Act 1996 (UK) - Implied right for employees to terminate employment with reasonable notice.
